pros: Great Support Excellent Training Rewarding
cons: Can be quite stressful at times and steep learning curve

job_title: Recruiter in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: - I love everyone in my team and that's hard to come by! Anyone I've met within the wider org have been lovely too. - So much autonomy and trust to manage your own time and work how best suits you - Affinity groups are a great way to relate to others and get to know more people
cons: - Sometimes IT issues slow things down - A bit more of an office presence would be nice

review_title: Great idea but the flaws need to be recognised.
job_title: Worked In Multiple Roles in Liverpool, England
pros: Training offered, people working there that do want to do well.
cons: For the Assessment Centre I had to go to London, as a person from the North, this is a long way. The allowence offered is not enough for train fare so I had to get a bus, this took 6 hours. I travelled through the night so I would be there for 9am. The assessment Centre was fine although I was the only working class person there, also the only Northern person. By the time I got the bus home I had been awake for over 48 hours and had been unable to afford food/drink for the journey. I was turned down as a candidate, which is fine. What I was uncomfortable with was the feedback I received. They explained that I passed the interview and I delivered a great lesson with appropriate material and confidence. But... 'I looked tired' (unable to afford train or hotel) and 'sometimes the panel struggled to understand what I was saying' (working-class accent). That was it, those were the reasons I was not considered as having the potential to become a teacher. Ironic thing is, I wanted to work at a school in my own area, the children would have had accents like mine. I would have been from a background like many of them which would hopefully show them that they too can go to university, which is supposed to be what teach first is about? Instead it is likely that a privately educated well spoken young person will take that place. Teaching kids that if they want to succeed they should become more middle class. I decided to take up a PhD studentship instead, researching class based discrimination in education. Teach First is often an example I use when teaching undergraduate students. Sometimes even the best intentions are clouded by a deeply rooted subconscious bias. It's in the very name of the organisation Teach underprivileged kids First, do something better later. Involving more people that share a background with these children may equate to teaching for life, not just first. I had worked for Teach First for a few years prior to this, promoting their schemes to high achieving students. Had I had this experience first, I would have been clear that this scheme is best suited to middle class students who would like to spend a couple of years amongst working class kids before going on to do something else.

pros: - consistent support online and in person - PGDE attained at the end of the two years - assignments enhance practice in the classroom - excellent network opportunities
cons: - heavy workload - additional support depends on school

pros: Do not go into teaching unless you are committed.

review_title: Great mission but can feel like you are cannon fodder

cons: Teaching is extremely demanding and teach first is no different

job_title: Secondary Teacher in Newcastle upon Tyne, England

cons: Poor pay and a significant workload

pros: The charity is filled with passionate, talented and dedicated people, who strive for an education system that works for every child, and support our community. As a whole, it's a really positive place to work. I always feel very supported internally, appreciate the available benefits and think my salary is reasonable.
cons: Career progression can be lacking due to budget restraints. At times, I've also felt there has been a lack of communication and planning when working on various projects.

review_title: They don't equip you to do your job then gaslight you into blaming yourself when you inevitably fail.
job_title: Teacher of Science in South Shields, England
pros: Being able to learn on the job.
cons: The teach first staff had no regard whatsoever for my wellbeing. They set me up to fail, then gaslit me into beliving it was all my fault. No one I was put with had any interest in providing me with the resources or information that I needed to do my job and instead left me to flounder and fail at the expence of my physical and metal health as well as the wellbeing and educations of the students. After a (thankfully) failed suicide attempt, this has left me with trauma that I am still working through years later.

pros:

Flexible working hours
Company very transparent with finances, challenges, upcoming plans for the year

cons:

High volumes of workload

job_title: Teach First Trainee Teacher in London, England
pros: Get paid to learn to teach. Get a 2 year contract.
cons:
Expect 10+ hour days at school, a long commute either side, and working from home in the evenings and on weekends.

The kids need a lot of additional help and support in the schools you are placed in but often the funding isn’t there to support them. So then you are left with extra responsibility. The children need expert teachers. Not novices.

Expect overwhelm from the start. I thought I was tough and would be able to take it in my stride. I was wrong.

You will lose your voice.

You will have a never ending to do list. I thought I was organised before. It turns out I was wrong.

pros:
- Generally supportive and useful training throughout the programme.
- Very social experience, particularly during Summer Institute.
- Reasonable level of support offered.
- Support with moving to a new area and finding flatmates who are also doing the LDP.
cons:
- Experience is hugely dependant on which school you end up in.
- Lots time consuming, seemingly-arbitrary box ticking exercises for Teach First.
- Appalling salary in first year.
- Lots of unpaid, out-of-hours work.
- Behaviour from pupils can be difficult to deal with, especially in the first year.
- Essays are very long (6,000 words twice an academic year) and time-consuming. Don't expect to 'relax' over the holidays, you'll be spending most days essay writing.
- The summer internships with big companies (pwc, accenture, etc...) have relatively few places reserved for TF participants and are consequently extremely competitive. Don't think that Teach First have reserved these places for its teachers.

pros: - They put you through your PGDE, so if you're planning on becoming a teacher, you save money on tuition fees.
cons:
- You do about a month and a half of unpaid training, followed by an unpaid month off, then you get your salary at the end of your first month working. So after having to travel several times for the assessment centre and the tests and the training, having to survive for three months without a wage, having to spend money on relocating and having to buy a laptop for summer institute, you're left with a lot of debt.
- You end up working 60 hour weeks and getting paid the bare minimum they can legally pay you as an unqualified teacher for your first year. If you work it out hourly in terms of all of the extra stuff you have to do at home, it's not even minimum wage.
- They place you in the worst schools in the UK right from the outset so you end up with massive behavioural management issues in your class which you've had only about 5 hours training on how to deal with.

job_title: Leadership Development Program in London, England
pros: Accelerated and salaried train to teach route.
cons: It is very difficult to juggle teaching and doing assignments.

review_title: Management needs improving, some good perks
pros: Great cause and lots of good work being done to achieve its goals, flexible working, great location and some really nice, hard-working people. Interesting work if you're able to seek it out for yourself and work independently. Pretty well paid for the sector. Very child friendly, helpful for flexible hours to collect children, and good maternity pay. Great induction process.
cons:
Some really terrible managers, no idea what they're doing or how to lead teams. Lots of unmotivated people trying to ignore it and get on with work. Very top heavy management, if you're well liked by them it's ok, but if not you won't be listened to and the same mistakes will happen with no consequences for management, only you. 
Role descriptions can often be quite vague and some managers don't offer you any support, sometimes will go out of their way to ignore you.
High turnover of staff, recruitment and HR process is very messy, be prepared to have your interview time changed multiple times. 
Endless meetings often unproductive. Bottlenecking in force - 1 person given so much work they can't cope and it causes bottlenecks for rest of org.

pros:
-Fantastic training where you gain so much insightful information about the programme so you are fully equipped when speaking to candidates
-Very friendly working culture where everyone is always willing to help and give guidance
-Seems to be lots of opportunities to move internally across the business giving lots of variety should you want a long term career with TF
-As good as work can get, you will not find a more rewarding/flexible job that appreciates a work life balance as much as TF
cons:
-Salary for coordinator is low and the gap between this and the application officer role is staggering
-There is a real lack of permanent opportunities across the business. Even long term employees are still on short term contracts which brings worry you feel your job isn’t particularly secure
-As the company encourages agile working, regularly managers aren’t in the office to appreciate the hard work of their team and reward them for achievements

pros: My colleagues at Teach First were excellent. They are  smart, committed, and fun. Many are Teach First Ambassadors and there is a lot of youthful enthusiasm at this organisation. There is lots of passion for the Teach First mission.
cons: In my experience, there was a regular lack of clarity from the leadership. There was a constant revolving door of employees-- including leadership. I also found their hiring decisions inconsistent-- sometimes there was a consensus that an excellent hire or promotion had been made and other times (more frequent than I would have wished), my colleagues and I were astounded by the appointment of inexperienced individuals who were offered roles beyond their capabilities or experience.

review_title: Nepotism is real but at least you can work from home
pros:
Flexible working arrangements 
Salary is good
Regular social events
Office in great location 
CEO is very visible which is very rare at organisations
cons:
It appears that people are promoted to senior positions because of who they know. Whilst one can argue that the individual was promoted because of their skills/capabilities, it is VERY convenient that these individuals are ‘close friends’ with hiring managers. 
An elitist organisation - the organisation aims to help kids from low socio-economical backgrounds and the organisation does not represent the people they wish to help...

pros:
Excellent work life balance and flexible working policies
Personally, I had some really excellent managers while there
Good colleagues
New CEO (since 2017) has done a lot to improve the organisation
cons:
Much of the IT team is quite poor - this may have improved since I left, but while I was there, internal systems were an utter mess
Restructurings were very frequent (once every 2 years on average)
It's not much fun if you are in your twenties - most of your colleagues have families and work from home on Fridays, so work socialisation is not amazing

pros: Flexibility, clarty of organisational vision, dynamic working culture, making a difference, creative colleagues, motivational work directly in UK schools, good benefits package, several UK offices, agile working environment. Inspiring vision. Good level of trust in employees.
cons: Sometimes employees need to take a lot of initiative to lead on their own professional development. Some inexperienced managers. A large organisation so decisions not always made or executed as swiftly as they could be.

job_title: L&D Business Partner in London, England
pros:
Amazing people. The best people I've ever worked with. A real sense of team, and commitment to each other and the mission of the charity.
Very forward-thinking charity. Great approach to flexible working, supporting you to work from any location and broadly choose hours that work for you (within reason).
cons: Few formal learning opportunities. But team people made up for this, in terms of development that came out of regular conversations with colleagues.

review_title: Doesn't stay true to it's values
pros:
Agile working and benefits.

Salaries are fair and in line with the industry
cons:
Within the IT department a recent change in senior management has resulted in a new culture of fear, blame and bullying to achieve results within an already overworked department.

This has been raised directly to the CEO on multiple occasions and ignored.

Given how this this behavior is well known and several people have spoken up it would suggest it is tolerated if not endorsed by the Exec level?

pros: Vibrant office, youthful, dynamic, energetic. Fun place to work. Very good agile working policy.
cons: Takes ages to get things done - leadership often say yes to things without considering the wider implications

review_title: Flexible, caring employer working towards a meaningful mission
pros: Flexible, family-friendly and trust you to get the job done.
cons: As a part-time employee I find that too much of my working week is taken up with meetings.

review_title: Brilliant organistaion. High-paced and large workloads but fantastic progression
pros: Great benefits, engaging colleagues, varied workloads, fantastic progression opportunities like pay rises, development, externship, sabbaticals.
cons: Large workloads, high expectations, too much jargon.

pros:
Teaching qualification is paid for 
Hands on experience
cons:
Lots to juggle. Training full time as teacher plus two year PGDE with four dissertation length essays
Communication issues between university and Teach First

review_title: Good experience, training and exposure to people.
pros: Flexible working hours, large potential for contributions to projects.
cons: Difficult to manage workload with too small a team ( unlikely at universities with a large Teach First presence)

pros:
- Company culture 
- Salary for charity sector 
- Fast-paced and high energy
cons: - Always changing due to contract changes, but that's to be expected in a charity

review_title: Great but too much work load
pros:
Working with different individuals at all levels of the company
Hosting and creating own events
cons: Sometimes its hard to balance being a student and work for teachfirst also

job_title: Human Resources Manager in London, England
pros: flexibility for all staff, particularly parents, ethos of trying to do better at all times, purpose and values driven
cons: over-commitment to everything meant intense busy-ness

pros: The staff were supportive and caring
cons: The behaviour policy wasn't well organised

pros: Amazing people, great vision, loads of development.
cons: Sometimes abit like a cult, no pay progression within some roles,

job_title: Secondary Math Teacher in Cambridge, England
pros: Fantastic leadership development and skills-building course, whilst making a positive difference to educational equality.
cons: At times, teaching is an extremely testing profession!

pros: Great vision, brilliant people to learn from
cons: Inexperienced Leadership team, who are extremely intelligent but do not have the relevant experience

pros: Flexible, manageable, enjoyable and the job varies every day
cons:

No one always on-site to get help from

pros: Valuable experience, loved the training day!
cons: Not much structure, sometimes too much left on your own, role not always interesting

pros: Great talent and training providers
cons: Highly intensive and challenging and very dependent on your placement

pros: Company has a strong social purpose, felt like I was making a difference
cons: Very little support and opportunities for development
